content:
Posted: January 12
												I backed Battle of Stalingrad as a founder back before release, and recently moved it to steam and grabbed Battle of Moscow, so my actual playtime is much higher than it states here. I have also flown many other simulations in the past too, from Falcon 4.0 to DCS World and IL-2: 1946.The IL-2 Battle of X series is an outstanding World War Two survey-level flight simulation.(Thus effectively REQUIRES at MINIMUM a joystick to enjoy properly) Single player is a little dull and repetitive, but multiplayer is where the fun is. Many will not like that, as flight sims have a massive trend of players sticking to single-player modes outnumbering online players by at least 10 to 1, but the shift to an online focus is increasingly common in the gaming industry as of 2017. IL-2 BoS follows this trend for better or worse.Immersion is the highest I have ever found in a flight sim, with the graphics (recently upgraded from DX9 to DX11 for FREE) audio and feel combining to create perhaps the most fully-realised representation of a frontline air war to date.The flight modelling, by and large, is outstanding. The only simulation to surpass Il-2 Battle of Stalingrad/Moscow/Kuban is DCS World, which at the time of this review does NOT have a WWII terrain, ground units or environment of any kind, just 4 standalone, study-sim level WWII aircraft. IL-2 flight models are targeted to be within 5% margins of error, and are often adjusted to even tighter tolerances when available flight data allows. There are some outlying issues however, most notably the Fw-190A3 (UPDATE: Fw-190A3 Has now been fixed) and P-40E-1. The former having issues with stick travel to stall and roll rate, and the P-40 incorrectly being rated at post-war, peacetime power settings. Also of note is the fact that the Battle of Moscow expansion pack aircraft have notably more realistic rudder/roll relationships, as shown by the Bf.109 E-7 to F-4 comparison often cited on the official forum. Both the Fw-190 and rudder issues have been confirmed to be getting fixes, and the devs have stated they are looking into the P-40. The Fw-190 issue in particular will be backported from the new Fw-190A5 coming with the Battle of Kuban expansion, regardless of whether or not the Fw-190A-3 owner purchases BoK. This has, in my eyes, (especially with the free DX11 update in Dec. 2016) shown that the developers not only care about the product, but are willing to continue work and updates to years old work in order to improve the sim as a whole.

												I have played nearly every flightsim on the pc market (and the amiga before that) to date.Most sims are locked in procedures , buttons you have to click preparations you have to make. But something is missing there, that world does not really come to life (I love DCS for example , but it sometimes feels like too perfect). AI oponnents are either superhuman or helpless canonfodderI always had that soft spot for sims that are actually about the flying itself, fighting the sick and gravity and gliding that wing. IL-2 Sturmovik: Battle of Stalingrad, does actually that , the ju52 actually flies different from the FW190, you just feel so powerfull in the wulf and helpless in the junkers. And then you did not press that damn trigger yet.Every plane is actually a different experience, its fun to fly the i16 and score on the bf109. This sim is never the same , things happen and you never know what to expect.yes some things are "missing" , the clickable cockpits it a thingy but no pilot had a mouse in the cockpit and mouses work fine in helos and jets but not in wobbly bobbly prop fighters.Map out the buttons , print a button sheet like in the old days , you will see ur soooo much faster than moving the mouse around to adjust prop pitch.A little more content (ground armour) would be nice , and i would love to fly a four prop bomber. content:
Posted: April 17
												Sims always require a learning curve. But few titles actually let you enjoy learning them. As with Rise of Flight, Il-2 BOS builds a world and it uses each plane to let you express yourself in that world. When IL-2 BOS makes compromises, it does so in the name of quality of simulation. Simulators are not a dying breed, anymore than they were back in the 2000s, when only IL-2 1946 refused to let the dream die. But quality is dying. Few teams are willing to go the extra mile, to make the extra effort. IL-2 BOS went beyond that, and they haven't stopped yet. 20 years ago, when I've played my first sim, I had a dream, that one day I would be able to feel that I am flying, in a sim, in my room. Now, with VR, a decent joystick and a few more gray hairs on my head, that dream has been fulfilled. Make no mistake, this is the killer VR app we've been waiting for. As for the sim players, you're probably here already anyway.

												Don't let yourselves be fooled by the title : This isn't an Il-2 series title. It features an Il-2 as part of the planeset, and the action takes place on the Eastern front during WWII, but the similarities end there. This game is 777 Studio's "Rise Of Flight" with WWII planes in a WWII setting. Bland environment, empty battlefields, a very disappointing SP experience and paid unlocks and flyable planes. In fact, "Il-2 BoS" may well be the very antithesis of what made the original Il2 such a great and long-running sim. I do not recommend this title to fans of the original Il-2 series, although RoF afficionados might appreciate the change of scenery within a familiar format.

												I'm amazed at this game. Here's my experience:I look over my shoulder to see my wingman in a line abreast formation a couple hundred meters away. His 6 o'clock is clear and I glance anxiously above every so often for the cold contrails of a 109 on the hunt, looking to bounce us. The snowy Russian steppe stretches out beneath us. Sunlight filters through a broken layer of low clouds. We flit in and out of them periodically. My engine drones on and I adjust the RPM setting. The engine note rumbles lower. I lean over the edge of the cockpit window and verify my fuel gauge reads above 20. I adjust the mixture setting. Again. I glance at my comrade. THERES AN AIRCRAFT DIVING ON HIS HIGH 6! "BREAK BREAK BREAK!", I yell. I slam the throttle and prop controls to FULL and dive after them. This $UC*ER is not getting my wingman I think to myself. And the game is on...ONE. WORD.IMMERSION!Play this game if thats what you are looking for in a WW2 air combat sim. Nothing else comes close.Oh, and learn to taxi. Thats is all.  :)

												I'm not sure I can play the old IL-2 1946 any more after owning IL-2 Battle of Stalingrad - it will seem way too easy.  I got the Moscow pre-release planes too - $160 within two days.  Could it possibly be worth that much?  What, ten or twelve bucks per flyable plane? Having spent probably something near that total figure on 777's other brilliant sim, Rise of Flight  and owning all those WWI aircraft and many paid plane mods, and knowing I'd do it all again, yes, it is worth that much to an old flight simmer like me.  I'll pay good money for a unique and excellent product.  It's probably the closest thing so far to flying the real things, though of course that is a guess.  I've never actually flown a LAG 3 but the sim just feels right. This game makes me feel very immersed and I am really enjoying it.  I am doing campaigns now - great fun.    I've already got half the paint schemes unlocked on three planes.  Very challenging flight models, gunnery, landings, etc.  Looks great - graphics are top notch.  Seemingly for serious simmers, but everyone should give it a try if you love these old aircraft and the period history.  Buy a decent joystick - keyboard and mouse won't do.   I got the premium packages because I couldn't wait to fly all the birds.  Get this game and get ready to practice your stick and rudder, as well as shooting skills.  Thank you very much, 777 Studios.  Flight simmers can count on you to keep the fire burning !!!

content:
Posted: February 10
												The game had a really bumpy start, with weird design choices for the campaign, forced unlocks in single-player, auto-scaling AI where the player has zero control over how difficult it is, very restricted multiplayer servers, non-existing custom missions, and poor optimization.I'm really glad to see that basically all of the above is fixed. There are now a lot of custom servers online after the editor was made publicly available, some with really impressive campaigns, the game now supports DX11 instead of only DX9 which has done wonders for optimization, proper VR support is on the way, flight models have been improved across the board, Battle of Kuban will come with a dynamic campaign, the unlock-crap has been partially solved since it wasn't popular, and we're seeing a lot of interesting options coming for plane loadouts and even in new planes.777 Studios dropped the ball pretty hard in the beginning, but they've certainly picked it up and are doing wonders at this point. IL-2 Battle of Stalingrad/Moscow/Kuban has become truly amazing! One of the best "saves" by a developer well on the way towards failure that I've seen to date.

												Like all games ever nowadays, this has been released as a pre-release of what could be a really really great game but may never actually get there.Even so, it offers the best atmosphere and realism possible in an approachable package for a reasonable amount of money. The complexity of flying is scalable, so one can just have fun shooting at other airplanes rather than spending hours upon hours learning why a BF-109 hasn't got elevator trim but a FW-190 does. 												Ok, So im not going to lie. When i was thinking of buying this i thought "its just going to be like IL2 Cliffs Over Dover (Clod for short) but now in russia. MAN I WAS WRONG!! For those of you that have played the oringal IL2: 1946 this IL2 is more like that!! The cockpits arnt fully clickable to my knowledge but you forgive that when you only 100m in the air skimming buildings whilst looking at your oponents tail with all the bullet holes in it. Trying to keep this short if you was to buy anyt WWII fighter game for now this will be it. I would say its unfair to relate it to cliffs over dover as it has all the RAF planes. Battle of Stalingrad has a different style of simulation where i beleive its the Dogfight/ground attack you are simulating rarther than the aircraft itself. Yes, you still manage your egine, flaps, RPM take offs, landings, turning your plane on/off but it will will be pressing  "L" to turn your lights on rather looking for the switch. Also it will tell you in the corner what type of failure you have if you get hit. As ever the failures are realistic as useual and it will be up to you as the pilot to decide wither to turn back and go home or to see if you can survive one last bombrun. I cant stress enough that this is still a simulator and should be treated as such. But i really think that that hint of arcade message in the corner that says " Egine coolent system Damaged" or "right Airlon Rod Stuck" reminds you that this is also a game and its here to be played rather than to be taken seriously! Bottom line is. Buy it.... its fun!!

												This is by far, the best flight sim I've ever played. I have yet to see a flight sim that rivals this game in terms of physics and damage models. And as a player who used to play Warthunder beforehand I've noticed a huge difference in the game. And I had to basically relearn everything from taxiing, actual combat, and landing.Each plane has been meticulously designed and rendered in great detail. From the instruments on the cockpit, to the way the plane behaves. Every plane has it's own unique features that make it stand out from the rest. And that is all complemented by the awesome graphics this game has.Be mindful that this game has a steep learning curve, it's not your typical flight sim. Overall, I highly recommend this game to all you flight sim enthusiasts who want to have a  real  flight sim experience. Pros:	- Great physics.- Awesome graphics- True to life aircraft recreations, all down to the last detail.- A very helpful playerbase Cons: - Very steep learning curve, you won't get any "easy kills" unless you have a proper understanding of how your plane works.- Issues with server connectivity.- Occasional unbalanced matches.- Small playerbase, but still a great and helpful community nonetheless.

Posted: December 4, 2015
												WOW !! I had this game on my wishlist for a year I think, before I decided to give it a try. It wasnt even on sale, and went on sale a week after I bought it, I was enjoying it so much I didnt even care. This is the reason for my HOTAS right now. The game really puts you there in the planes, the immersion is deep, the learning curve is steep ( and rewarding) and the ground is unflinching when you plummit to your demise. There are so many little things in this game that I like, the noise that your plane makes when its taken a few too many hits, the sense of accomplishment when you finally stick a post misson landing and get that 50% bonus for actually landing in one piece. The OH CRAP feeling when you unsettle your attack approch by shooting rockets off one at a time and upset the glide path of your plane etc etc etc , I really like it I swear I can smell the exhaust when I start up for a mission. I liked it so much I went and bought 1/72 models of my favorite planes to put together ha ha ha ha . Oh and the multiplayer is pretty cool too, although not a huge number of people I have been able to join at least one server anytime to find other players to annoy with my noob_ness. A cool touch also for the multiplayer is being able to crew a gun station on a friends plane and vise-versa. If you like a no-bs sim style combat game this may be for you. The only negatives that I have for this game is that it is centered around a specific time and place, and that means a limited assortment of aircraft to fly. I understood this going in ( its all in the name after all) but I would love to see the scope of this game expanded. I dont hold this against the game, but I could see how some may have no interest in the specific planes on offer, so make sure you know what is included before making a decision. the second negative is the somewhat low number of players in multiplayer, there are enough to get into a game generally during most times, the servers arent exactly bursting full. ( the unfortunate side effect being you will play with alot of the same people) this I hope will improve over time. thats all i have to say . One of the esiest thumbs up I have given yet.

Posted: November 2, 2015
												Alot of the reviews for this game state that its "not what I had hoped for " or "dissapointing". I was really worried when purchasing this but Im really glad I did. I played Il2 Cliffs of Dover casually as the game was a bit of a strain for me (the cockpits were so well detailed it actually hurt my eyes, framerate was generally not great, UI was awful) even so I expected a great deal of detail and polish in Il2 Battle of Stalingrad and it definitely has it. In my opinion one of the most important parts of an immersive simulator are the sound effects and this game has it spot on, the engines and various other effects sound great and authentic. The graphics are quite good as well (especially the aircraft). The game itself plays very well with  aircraft responding realistically to stalling and rough maneuvering. The game while not great as far as optimization goes still runs better than Cliffs of Dover and even when low in framrate still runs strangely smooth. The damage models are very detailed with basically any part of the aircraft being able to come off (I must've spent 3 hours plowing aircraft into the ground watching the wings flex and break). The UI is well designed and a staggering improvement from the one seen in Cliffs of Dover.But there are also a few low point in the game like the lack of clickable cockpits. One of my favorite point of Cliffs of Dover was having the completely manual control of aircraft and while Battle of Stalingrad does support it with keyboard binding available I much rather have the option of clickable cockpits. The game can also get repedetive as far as the campaign goes with you generally having the same objectives dependent on which mission type you select. But even with that in consideration I still come back to Il2 daily.I got Il2 BoS for $30 over a sale and at that price its a good deal, but at $50 im not sure I can recommend it. So wait for a sale and definitely pick it up if you have even a moderate fondness for aircraft simulators (like I do).

content:
Posted: January 9, 2016
												IL-2 BoS is sort of like War Thunder minus all the things I hated about War Thunder.That's going to be controversial, because a lot of people are posting reviews doing everything they can to prove that IL-2 is //NOTHING!!!// like War Thunder... but it is. And that's not a bad thing!BoS hits the same "accessible realism" point that something like War Thunder (mainly sim mode, but "normal" settings in BoS include markers and automatic engine management) hits. Neither are the rivet-counting, absolute to the metal fidelity that something like DCS strives to be (I play a lot of DCS too, by the by), but both War Thunder (outside of arcade battles) and BoS are VERY far from the more arcadey, easy to learn experience that an air combat game like Crimson Skies might be. BoS even has an experimental mouse-aim mode for potential aviators who don't have joysticks, though from what I understand the implementation is very rough around the edges at the moment.The main differences in BoS and War Thunder are why I much prefer the former to the latter. War Thunder's primary problems are the free-to-play grind that you have to expect from... well, a free-to-play game (BoS has a progression system that is a tooooouch grindy, as well, but none of the unlocks are really game changing and you can grind them out in singleplayer if you want), and the very questionable flight models and balancing that everyone just sort of accepts as standard from the game now. In BoS, you won't be clubbed by a fighter that's severely over-performing, and you won't be crippled for flying an aircraft you enjoy because it under-performs or finds itself facing unreasonably stiff opposition. Honestly, in BoS, most of the (fighter) aircraft are pretty evenly matched- even the premiums (I fear the 109 pilot over the 190). I've even had semi-successful engagements flying a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed IL-2 up against fighters, because at the end of the day a skilled pilot (which I am not- hence the SEMI-successful nature of those engagements) will win no matter his aircraft... and the IL-2 has much better low speed performance than any fighter in the game so dragging♥♥♥♥♥♥sure Bubi-wannabes into low-speed duels is a very good way to embarass the Luftwaffe.All these comparisons to War Thunder aside- you will need a joystick to fully enjoy IL-2: BoS. Preferably one with a rudder axis (Rudder is SUPER IMPORTANT on these old prop aircraft for managing sideslip) and a throttle flapper. You can find a stick like that for like $15-$20, usually. Also, some form of headtracking makes dogfighting, especially on full-realism servers without markets, MUCH easier (maintaining situational awareness is a big part of being a successful combat pilot)- you can build a headtracker with rudimentary knowledge of how to solder and about $30 in materials, or if you have an android smartphone I hear that there are ways to use that, strapped to a headset or something, to get 3-DOF (as in, you won't be able to lean around in the cockpit, but you can look left and right and up and down) headtracking that works decently well. If you're not able or willing to do any of those, you can map your view controls to a hat on your joystick or something, and that should be serviceable.So yeah- If you enjoyed War Thunder when it wasn't harassing you with awful game design and sketchy as frig flight models, and you're okay with a more limited roster of flyable aircraft, AND you're okay with flying with a joystick (until the devs polish mouse aim), pick this game up. It's enormous fun, even flying ground attack or a bomber like the Peshka or the Heinkel (though I do wish you could get magnetic bearing to target in those aircraft, flying bombing approaches on smaller targets without it is a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥♥, and you'll end every fight with a dumb grin even if its you who ended up a fiery ball of dead airplane on the ground. And if you're more a study-sim guy (like I am, honestly), don't gloss over BoS as just-another-WWII-plane-game, it's plenty realistic enough that really only noncombat systems are streamlined (and radios, but we all know you fly with easy communication on in DCS, anyway).

content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												It almost feels like you are flying. I've been playing flight sims for the past 20 years and this games nails the sensation of flight better than any other. Multiplayer is a blast and it takes less than 30 seconds from the time you launch the game to the time you are flying on a server. It is also deep but accessible. You can play on Normal servers with radar, tagging of planes, a HUD, and autopilot or you can play on Expert servers with none of these assists. So why all the bad reviews? Here is a summary of the most common:"I can't get it to work!" Read the install instructions and register online. You only have to do it once and it is the least invasive DRM on Steam."DLC and unlocks have no place in an unfinished flight sim." I can't disagree, especially since the German FW190 is only available as DLC. This was the second most iconic German fighter of the war and should have been made available to all from the start. The Russian La-5 was seldom flown so that is understandable as DLC but the German offering should have been one of the two variations of the 109 Messerschmitt already in the game. Even if you do not take part in the DLC or unlocks, IL-2 BOS has the most enjoyable online dogfights out there and is a worthwhile purchase for anyone interested in a combat flight sim.

												IL2 Stalingrad and Moscow have really come a long way since first released (more like a rough work in progress Beta initially).  They have been good about releasing on-going upgrades, and though not perfect, I think its better than alternatives out there for the mix of sim and immersion.  Not as sim as the prior Cliffs of Dover, but MUCH more playable (without the 3rd party Mods, it was broken). DCS has some great stuff as well, but missing the WWII environment (or not without a lot of modding effort).  With their recent Kuban expansion plans, it shows commitment to meaningful continued improvements.  I'm really glad I hung in there and have seen IL2 develop to the point it is now, especially with the pending improvements.  As for gripes, I believe they have a bit of Soviet bias in the modeling, but its liveable and I hope it sees some tweaks.  Single player "story" at the moment is a bit weak, but once flying in game, its good.   Kuban related releases upcoming are addressing the single player aspect.

												Taxiing: Bloody hard. Tailspins...sheesh....crazy stuff. But once you get sorted, pointing straight down the runway open the throttle slowly...and away you go...open your oil radiator, inlet/outlet cowls a bit...and varoom, you're flying. After the learning curve of taking off, flying the planes is a short lived relief...then you gotta spend a few hours or more learning how to land without cracking up your airplane. It's really frustrating in the beginning, so be prepared to practice these things again and again. Then there's combat. By Gum there's stone cold air aces out there, and they will flame you more than you like  until you learn the rudiments of combat. I recommend trying against the AIs for a bit, till you get a bit more comfy with combat, including the fact that these aircraft can be very unforgiving on you if you abuse them. Spins will be common, and half the fun is learning how to get out of them. I find Cliffs of Dover to be a better sim in many ways, but this one is no slouch. It is also a lot of fun with a great community of "pilots"...so yes, I recommend it. 4/5 stars.

												Pros:+true combat flight sim experience+reasonably well graphics for a modern flight simulation+great sound and damage effects+authentic flight models and no russian bias like in other russian made "simulations"+actively played on multiplayer+still in devellopement: with "Battle of Moscow" and later probably more DLC's comming up   this game will stay in the attention focus of players and will be part of something bigger in the future.Cons:-Very demanding on pc's performance espacially the CPU-There are issues with the view range. You won't see planes that are further away then 10km at all and everything further then 3km is very hard to spot.-The singleplayer campaign is pretty liveless and boring (they are improving it though)-No clickable cockpits like in "Cliffs of Dover"A few words on the pricing and DLC politics:If you think Battle of Stalingrad is expensive keep in minde that producing flight sims is at least as expensive if not more expensive then producing a mainstream game that is supposed to be bought by houndred thousands players.But flight sims aren't bought by houndred thousands players as the playerbase for such titles is quite small.Thus the "high" price. Even though I can understand that the company needs to make money with the game I think cutting out planes from the game isn't the best solution (Fw-190/La-5) but at least those planes aren't "pay to win" in the multiplayer. My recomendation: If you want these planes, simply wait for a sale to get them cheaper.The splitting of the game in big DLC's and working on them one after another to add to a greater game is in my oppinion a great idea.  For one: this makes sure that every single part of the game is finished in a state that actually can be called finished. Flight sims are prone for bugs and flight models that are simply a bit off. Thats why they need time to "grow the beard". By splitting the project in peaces the game gets time to do that. (Think of what happened to Cliffs of Dover: Big game, took to long and cost to much money to finish and was rushed to the marked in a horrible state.)For now the patches of "Battle of Moscow" with its planes are allready integrated in "Battle of Stalingrad" even if you haven't purchased BoM. The only difference is, that you will not be able to fly its planes  untill you buy BoM. Still you will come across BoM's planes in singleplayer and multiplayers as allies and opponents.All in all I think Battle of Stalingrad is a fun flight sim with a promising future.(Fun enough to be a reason for me to replace my stoneage CPU)

												Lots of points to take on this game.My previous review has been rendered unfair to this title.Graphics: amazing, you will not feel any lack of believability worth of taking out performance. There's a lack of graphic options but this subject has been discussed to entirety on the forums; head there to take notes. The way it's done is adequate to multiplayer.Performance: I had flawless performance on my previous CPU, a dual core intel E7500. Upgraded to a i5 and it's marvelous.i5 4590 + gtx670 2gb + 8gb RAM on max settings.Multiplayer is being the most demanded feature now on games, fair enough. Battle of Stalingrad had a underwhelming release. It was far from broken, or bad release, but the features in it were not quite there.Now, BoS still counts with a very active community and passionate about the genre. Steady activities of Wings of Liberty (hardcore full sim with navigation assistance) servers and the normal difficulty ones (not my thing).Overall, multiplayer is amazing. New missions come and go on the servers and generally the players care about the objectives. If bored on those kind of missions and want more elaborated ones, you can take yourself to the mission editor on the game root file, make one and send to the server's hosts, exchange ideas, participate on the community.Single player is fun, not quite the thing I expected coming from RoF but is playable and offers immersion. Differently from the release, single player missions have more AI activity, is common to encounter other fights in the path of your objective or when returning to base.Physics: The best on the market. The damage model is unsurpassed since RoF. 777 studios really put love into this.Combat: as physics, probably the also best in the market. You can rip wings off from your oponent with a flow of structural damage unique. Belly landing with precision of forces. Cartridges explosion with HE cannon shells on the wings. Engine damage and fire damage adequately modeled. Tons of parts to rip off from the plane you'll feel that every shot down is unique in a certain way. Some adjustments are made into the flight model here and there, but certainly it got better since release and expect to be even more refined as more people get into the sim.Simulation vs arcade: It's a simulator.... but DCS has clickable cockpits....... yes, it still a simulator. Philosophies differs from other flight sims and combat sims. 777 studios kept a rather controversy philosophy in relation to pilot/player workload, but the rest are there, planes feel alive, fuel consumption, temperatures, real engine values from real life, it's all there.It's THE most lively experience of flying I've ever encountered in a desktop simulator. DCS comparison can be drawn with discussing it's differences. I freaking love DCS world (non steam standalone) and have a ton of hours in it, but both these sims have disadvantages and advantages in distinct areas. Both are amazing.New expansions are coming, new planes and updates to single player and world.A new summer map for BoS is in the merge of releasing with a ton other fixes and improvements.Before stopping my BoS gameplay in late 2014 - early 2015 I gave it a 6/10 for the actual features and state of it at the time. Now I can give a 7.5 with very solid hopes to surpass 9 points with great future expansions and features.Somewhat, it's a good time to be a flight simmer.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2016
TLDR : IL-2 Battle of Stalingrad is fairly limited, has a dull single-player campaign, and a poor multiplayer environment. The flight models are good, but the environment, graphics and sounds feel flat. It feels like a chore to play it.Full review : IL-2 Battle of Stalingrad (IL2:BoS) is a flight simulator set on the Eastern Front at the turning point of the Second World War. The battle and backdrop are epic, but this simulator does not do it justice. Technically, the game engine is pretty good, and the simulation of the flight, damage and world environment are actually quite good. However, the interface, presentation and engagement with the player are poor.There are a limited 8 aircraft in the game that you can fly, with a further two available as premium extras for purchase. Some of these are very similar (e.g. two variants of the Bf 109), making it feel even more limited. The implementations are okay, but there are some bugs which greatly detract from the experience. For example, there is a constantly flashing warning message telling you to retract the landing gear... on a Stuka (an aircraft with fixed undercarriage)! The aircraft have various degrees of automation, which I found frustrating. Another example is that the official paint-schemes are just a random assortment from throughout the war... such as desert camouflage in the Soviet Winter. Again, it doesn't stop gameplay, but it is detracting and unnecessary. Also, many of the interesting systems (radios, radar, navigations, etc.) are not implemented.The graphics are fairly flat, making it feel cartoon-like. The icons/interface overlay is cluttered and confusing. The sounds are okay, but the radio messages sound very repetitive and stilted (like badly automated railway announcements). There are also modern "beep" sounds, which detract from the ambiance.There is a multiplayer scene, but it is a bit quiet and lacking depth. However, the real let down is the single-player campaign. Rather than a career, where you can follow the progress of the squadron, get promotion, look after an individual aircraft and feel a sense of being there... the campaign is just a string of missions that feel randomly generated. There is some text and the missions work in themselves, but they feel very canned and lacking in depth. It is difficult to feel committed to them. Yes, there is an overall pilot rank and medals, but they are just for the gamer, and not for each individual career or aircraft.Even the "unlock system" is weak. I know that some players hate them. To the contrary, I actually really like the unlocks. It gives you a sense of accomplishing something. However, these unlocks are a bit dull. Just extra bombs or new paintschemes, and it is often possible to bag several at once, removing the sense of accomplishment.Although I've had this title for quite some time, and have an interest in the Eastern Front due to personal connection, I simply have not had any enthusiasm for this title. Given its age, it has already matured, so no significant development can be expected to improve the situation. For an arcade player, there are far more extensive titles. For the hard-core simulator enthusiast, IL2:BoS falls short.I do not recommend this title.

Assign ROLL trim to the horizontal axis of the hat switch. Use the hat switch with your thumb to stabilize your airplane in flight. -Adjust the response curve of your joystick in the KEY MAPPING options. There will be an option for all 3 axis of your joystick, ROLL, PITCH, and YAW.  Move the SENSITIVITY slider to between 75% - 90%. If your control response is still too sensitive increase the slider. Decrease the slider if the control response is sluggish.-Developers did not include anything like what most gamers would call a 'Campaign' or 'Story Mode'. BOS has a template for the community to create new scripted campaigns. The game is basically unplayable as a single player without installing some additional campaigns. content:
Posted: June 12, 2015
												I'm changing my review entirely.  This game took some serious warming up to.  Initially, I really didn't like it, but in the interest of not wasting 60 bucks, I kept at it and things got better.  As soon as the update came out where graphics settings could be tweaked, I finally found myself seeing other people before I was dead so I must admit, this helped a lot towards actually making the game fun.Since this is supposed to be a sim, I'll do my best to list what I feel like the positives and negatives are and what their bearing is on reality.On the plus side, the game is beautiful.  Undeniably, things look great.  This goes a long way to making you feel immersed.  Spotting is great as well.  Depending on where the sun is, the angle of the aircraft and their distance from you, things might get tricky when trying to keep an eye on your prey, pursuer or even your wingman for that matter.  Surface level winds are good as well.  They can cause some serious issues on takeoff and landing if you're not prepared.  Things sound good as well, although I know certain sounds have undergone an overhaul of late, listening to your aircraft can give some important indications as to its behaviour if you choose to turn the HUD off like I do.  Multiplayer is very good.  Don't expect to waltz in and dust everyone because the fact is...you won't.  That being said, for the experienced, I do feel like a clean bounce is still a very viable option.  I've found the level of experience on some games really takes away that aspect of combat, as everyone is competent and adept at clearing their six regularly.  Also, just yesterday, the summer and autumn maps came out so you don't have to look outside at a barren, white wasteland all the time anymore, which is a relief.  On the downside, there are still some very arcade-y elements to this game, most notably, and to the chagrin of myself and several of my friends, the start-up procedure....is entirely automated.  Press one button and engine start tasks are all performed by the computer.  The irony of it all and the infuriating part is that it still sometimes fails to start!  Whereby, the computer then shuts everything down while you wait 20 more seconds, only to press a single button again, and watch it repeat the process as you silently (or not) curse the game.  I've also seen some things that are...questionable to say the least.  I do fly the 109 almost exclusively and its acceleration and energy retention is second to none (in terms of the plane set in the game) but time after time, I've seen Yaks pull maneuvers that should rob them of all their energy and somehow come out without losing anything.  I've even seen a Yak catch a 190 going balls out on the deck, having started from equal altitude.  I know this may not mean anything to some, and it's impossible to speculate on all the variables like fuel state and loadout but let it be said that more than a few times I've cocked my head to the side and wondered "how?"  There is also the matter of single player and the unlock system.  The single worst idea the developers had and something the community has complained about since day one.  However, they still felt that implementing it into this game and the upcoming Battle of Moscow was a good plan.  I know there are some that like to play single player and for them, this won't matter.  But frankly, multiplayer is the heart of this game and to have to drag your♥♥♥♥♥through a bunch of boring single player missions just to unlock a paint scheme or two is not appealing in the slightest.  Lastly, and this isn't so much a negative as it is something I can't argue one way or the other; there doesn't seem to be much feeling in the controls.  Mind you, I don't have a force feedback stick but the aircraft does sometimes want to react very violently in circumstances where it shouldn't.  Personally, I needed to spend some serious time with my control settings to try and smooth things out to the point where I wasn't fighting it anymore.  All in all, this is a game worth checking out if you love flying.  If you want a perfect game, keep looking because you will never find it.  If you find yourself getting frustrated, keep at it because I felt the same way about it at first.  Real pilots and anyone who has even a few hours under their belt will find issue with parts of this game beyond a doubt, but the advantage here is that you get to shoot someone else down!

content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												An excellent new flight sim from the team that brought you Rise of Flight. Being an actual pilot myself I can personally endorse the game's flight model in accuracy and feel. The airplanes all feel great with realistic properties of weight to power and engine management. At first I was skeptical that their were so few planes and that new ones are $19.99, but so much effort goes into them and they're all so characteristic that I didn't find this to be nearly as big as problem as I thought would be. The much maligned unlock system is in my opionion one of the best features of the game. Giving the sim and campaign a structure previously unheard of these games. Their is a reason to push and work for rewards in the game and the way it's handled is tasteful and contextual to the conflict rather than childish as some people are claiming. A strong return to form for the IL-2 series and simultaneously a smashing sequel to the amazing Rise of Flight. I strongly recommend this sim to those with an open mind an interest in seeing the genre taken in a new direction. I eagerly await Battle of Moscow.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
												Why this is not a prefect simulation it does have enough good things that I will recommend it. Things I like about it.The flight models are done quite well.  It is a good challenge to fly some of these planes especially a couple of the German ones.  Take offs and landings are not a given,   Each plane fly's differently and are greatly effected by load-out and weight.   The damage model is diverse and can be quite epic at times.  Bomb and gun ballistics seemed accurate.  The campaigns are open and that it lets you choose either side.  You can also fly any plane and do any type of mission you want.  You advance the campaigns by completing missions regardless of which side you play or which plane you fly.   As you complete missions you earn upgrades for the aircraft you fly and unlock more airbases to launch from.  I found myself flying planes I would not normally fly because I enjoyed earning the upgrades for them.    The missions let you start in the air close to the objective or can earn more points and do a full mission which includes take off and landing.   It does have a time accel feature but it is 2X only.  The ability to play as gunner and bombardier is cool. Quick Mission setups and single missions are availableThe abiltiy to record and replay missions is another nice feature.Things I DislikedThe missions are always the same way-points.  Takeoff, Entry point, Action point, Exit point, Landing.  You can not add or edit any of the way-points.  No mission planning beyond your planes load-out.The friendly AI kind of sucks.  While not totally useless they crash way too much and have trouble keeping up.Non clickable cockpits.Weather effects are kind of bland and the constant winter environment gets old.In summary  IL-2 Sturmovik: Battle of Stalingrad is not my all time favorite but it us good enough to recommend to others who enjoy accurate flight simulations like myself.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2015
												If you are an offline player like myself, you will be left wanting more from the campaign.The game incorporates some very familiar elements from 777 and 1C. However it is a shame that the cockpit is not clickable, which is fine for ROF but in more complex aircraft, I was hoping for a IL2 ClOD situation.The campaign is not your classic campaign, I would say that it is almost the bare minimum. You are not part of a squadron, you do not fly consecutive missions which have a feeling of progression like in IL2 1946. basically you click an airfield like in ROF and choose a mission. Every time.....no airfield transfers, no front movements in the chapter, you can even switch sides every mission, there is also no time progression. For each mission you get XP. Expert mode gets you more XP, as well as safely landing your aircraft. With morexp come more unlocks, which don't actually hinder the game, and don't really keep you from enjoying the game if you don't have them.When you get enough XP, the next chapter simply becomes available. There is is still a lot of work to be done here because honestly in reference to ROF, this campaign is not even beta, it is sub par.That being said the game is IN development. The campaign system IS being addressed and I am very excited for the announced upcoming updates. Maybe when the game has a more stable and finished overall environment developed Desastersoft could pick it up, who knows. The thing is the Devs are really working hard on making this game up to their own personal standards (despite various financing problems and the fact that this isn't a very sim firendly market)The game is a good successor to IL2 1946. It just needs polishing, but IL2 1946 WAS a much simpler game, where you could add new planes in a months time. This is not possible with the level of detail in BOS.The map is huge and wonderful. Cockpits and planes look fantastic. The gun effects, explosions, lighting it is all very next gen. It is a huuuuge improvement and a great leap forward. Even though I am honestly not entirely satisfied, I would 10/10 recommend this game. Too bad we already have one of those, and it's called War Thunder. Cons:Many-No Native Oculus Rift support (When the game was demo'd with the DK1 earlier this year)-Pitiful Flight Models. The actual flight characteristics in the air are decent, but on the ground are rubbish.-No Manual mode for engine control and startup.-Unlocks are only obtained in single player grinding, which is HORRIFIC at best. I would be ok with unlocks like this if they were only skins or ways to mark your plane, but instead they're also for weapons, bombs, machine guns, armor, etc. This makes the game unbalanced for the people who don't have hours upon hours of time to spend in Single Player unlocking basic things.-Game requires you log in at the start of each session even for single player, no internet = no play-Servers are shaky at best, you can barely stay connected for more than one round, and the rounds are only 20-40 minutes long which means it's only for those people who want "quick" action, and not mission based online play.-Impossible to win in "Full Realism" without trackIR or some form of head tracking (be warned)In final, this is not a sim. This is an arcade version of IL2 with some niceities added in for hardcore people. If you're an avid flyer DO NOT BUY. Stick to IL2 1946 or IL2 CLOD, the community is better, there's content still being produced for those by private parties. I wont deny that the game is fun, but for the price you pay it's not worth it's retail tag. This should have been released as a Free 2 Play with an item mall. Instead they charge you $XX and then give you the bare items to play, with the same UNREASONABLE expectations for grinding out unlocks. At least with Heroes and Generals I could goto the item mall instead of wasting my time in the stupid monontenous campaign to get an item that I actually need to use the plane in the first place.DO NOT BUY WASTE OF MONEY.I would have not bought this if it wasn't on the steam sale, and even those prices are too high.For the standard it should be $20, and the Deluxe it should be $25.That's all this game is worth. content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												Let me start this off by saying the game is technically finished, but still is adding and completing the game.After signing up on IL2's website, and starting up the game I was immediately hit with a few tiny problems.  One was that I have to reset the game for fullscreen to take affect, and then have to restart it again after the screen resolution was really wack.  Once that was sorted I jumped into a quick mission and was thrown into the good ol' fashioned IL2 experience that veterans love and newbies will be able to grasp like their own genitalia.  First thing you'll notice menu wise is that they're very sleek, and easy to use.  Unlike their usual menu's that are rather strange, buggy or just plain dull, this one is a very nice change of pace.  The options are clear, the writing is slick and the essential options are big and easy to see, aswell as functional unlike the previous installment (Cliffs of Dover) where loadouts wouldnt even be selectable for some strange and unknown reason, the game has a lock beside all the modifications letting you know theyre unlockables, and not just given to you.Gameplay wise the game has a ton of options, allowing for an easy 'Normal' or 'Expert' difficulties to be picked making it easy to start the game up for a quick match for those who just want to play, or just to differentiate where begginers and veterans should be starting off at.  Most noteably out of all the gameplay options is the campaign, this is (to my knowledge) the only real flight sim that starts players off with a quick, helpful tutorial that shows players how to work the campaign mission selector and standardized mission plans.  The campaign has a lot of unique features such as stats that can be viewed from the web, and a 'Full Mission' or 'Quick Mission' options that let players choose if they want to start in the air ready to go, or have to take off and land.  Combat is as standard as simulators come, detailed models, realistic flight mechanics, bullet drop, all the basic stuff.   The only complaints I have is that they removed click cockpit and gave us only four planes per faction (five if you wanna dish out some extra coin) that dont offer us the same depth that the planes in Cliffs of Dover did,Visually the game is stunning, beautiful vast open landscapes that are nicely brought to life.  The game really captures the battle as it was fought in the air, and on the ground.  All flight sims are visually stunning in the air, focusing on cloud effects and sun effects ETC....  But Battle of Stalingrad makes an attempt to make you have a bit more of a reason to look down other than trying to bomb the crap out of the place, adding some unique smoke effects that billow out from the town which drew my attention during my long stretches back to base and actually impressed me.  However, the onlu problem I have with the graphics is that there is no way to make custom graphics settings, its just four options; Ultra, High, Balanced, and Low.Overall, the game is definitely worth a buy if you're a veteran of flight sims looking for a new one to add to your library.  I do also recommend that if people are looking at getting into flight sims this is one game that can be easy to start off with, I do HIGHLY RECOMMEND that if you're getting this as your first flight sim that you buy a joystick, or you'll be key mapping for hours.  For veterans I also recommend a Track IR system, it makes the game way more immersive and gives you a tactical edge when in multiplayer.Frankly, the people who dislike this game are people who have played War Thunder and bought this on impulse.  The usual complaints are that the game is not user friendly or that it has not enough playability or plane diversity.  I agree that the dev's made a stupid decision to make DLC planes that are as famous as the FW190 and LA5 so expensive and DLC at all, but the planes we are given all have unique play styles and need lots of practice to even come close to mastering them, and the game is meant to be grueling and difficult as its supposed to be simulating.  The planes we have are all very nice and fun to use and although there arent as many as we would probably like, its a quality over quantity type deal.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												The perfect settingWesterners dream of Spitfires dancing over white cliffs and Mustangs crushing Berlin. There is reason to celebrate this. But history is cold to dreams, and indifferent to sentimentality. History knows that Western Civilization pivoted in the slushy depths of the Volga in 1942. And we all inhabit the world carved out by these inglorious warriors, their blood; long forgotten. 1c didn’t forget. And they’ve teamed up with 777 studios to remind another generation of simjocks what the frozen brutality of the Eastern Front was all about.The A TeamCombining the forces behind “IL-2 Sturmovik” with “Rise of Flight” is a dream-come-true and a tough legacy to live up to. Expectations could not be higher. What’s PerfectThe aircraft are expertly modeled and flying them is a pure joy. Individual aircraft showcase historic behaviors.  The atmosphere ignores, aids, or intrudes as it will. Complex flight dynamics will please veterans and challenge newcomers. Battle of Stalingrad may be considered that rarest of things: A Combat Flight Simulator. What’s GoodThe aircraft are meticulously detailed. Remaining more simplistic than “study sims”, BoS showcases enough detail to set it apart from rival ‘combat’ simulations. In-flight engine systems are modeled, yet may be simplified by the player. Engine components and flight surfaces succumb to stress and mismanagement. Everything is dependent on individual aircraft and realism settings. What’s BadWhile beautifully modeled, the plane set is anemic. And there are no (at this time) AI only planes to flesh out the missions. The settings in general have little variety and shoehorn graphics and realism settings together. Single player jocks seem especially misconsidered. The multi-player, depending on geography, may find few populated servers. There are also “unlockable” skins, load outs, and field modifications. While not much of a practical hindrance, this mentality is a poor portent. What’s UglyWhile the “early access” model is new to most gamers, flight jocks are well familiar with games that sell copies with promises of things to come. Battle of Stalingrad well takes advantage of a hard-core base by releasing a game that’s clearly not finished. We all drool at the prospect of Theatres of war to come. And I applaud studios that leave this door open. However, there are plenty of areas where this game lacks basic features. For example, there is no manual. For a game as complex, with a learning curve so steep, this is an obscene omission. Conclusion:Battle of Stalingrad is a gorgeous combat flight simulator with no qualifier. Its pedigree is suburb, even if its execution is flawed. While the game it may become is unclear, the game it is, remains excellent and should be had by every serious simjock. For the new-comer I would recommend only if you’ve a passion for combat simulation. Your orientation will be graciously met by the community, not by the developers, Only passion and hard work will see you through the steep learning curve to frozen glory.

												I've played this series since the first one came out in 2001 or so. Just picked this up this week and so far, I'm still impressed. I don't fall head-over-heels in love with games, but 777 studios and 1C studios has never been a let down!One thing these games have taught me - I absolutely SUCK and combat sims. I will admit though, sucking at flying the planes in this series has never felt so good and been this much fun! (Although sucking at combat sims has, somehow, made me quite good at regular flight sims)Attempt 1 = take off. Line up with my squadron. First one goes fine. Second one goes fine. I go, spin out, drop my landing gear on the runway, break a wing off, bend my plane almost in half and sit there smoking. Next plane goes, runs over my landing gear, tearing their front wheels off, causing them to face-plant into the runway and somersault for several feet.Attempt 2 = Decide to abandon my squadron (for their safety) and taxi to a side taxiway to take off. Engines good. Rudder positioned. Reach takeoff speed and plane barely leaves ground. Struggle with struggling plane, and tear off my left wing off on a tree, whipping me around in circles. Scratch my head, watch replay and realize I never lowered my flaps... DOH!Attempt 3 = Begin airborne since I seem to suffer a major case of suckage at taking off. Misread mission map and fly away from my squadron, and from the checkpoint for about 5 minutes. Fix my mistake and arrive late to the party. Fire at an enemy and damage my teammate. Take 2 rounds from enemy plane and my engine goes up in a cloud of smoke, covering the cockpit in a sticky black oil. I blindly coax my plane along, lowering the throttle and using my map as guidance. Engine kicks the bucket with about 30 miles left to go... yep, screwed. Can't see the ground, can't see anything really. I keep it level, looking out the side of my cockpit and aim for, what looks like an empty field. Landing gear is down and flaps are lowered, so far so good.Slam head-first into a house and explode in a fireball, taking the house out with me.As I said, sucking never felt so good :)

content:
Posted: December 24, 2015
												If you only play singleplayer then I would search up more about the randomly generated campaigns, if there is one thing this game is missing is immersve campaign missions. There are many single missions but no continuous story. It is no where near as modifiable as previous games. The campaigns are decently long with average variability, the generated missions do get repetitive but the game itself is still fun enough to draw you back.The multiplayer is much more varied and really is where this game shines. You can have a simple dogfight or partake in a long and enduring battle over a massive area with several mission to keep you occupied. Tanks have also made an appearance (for free) and are relatively fun for the small impression they've left so far (early in development at the time of writing).The quality of the simulation aspect is as expected, you will not be disappointed. The only downside is that the cockpit is not fully interactable (like in DCS) but all functions are still usable.With the release of Battle of Moscow the game community has NOT been split, in fact you will own half of BoM by simply owning BoS. Put simply you will be able to fly with and against aircraft from BoM but not fly them yourself.If you want to experience both solo and multiplayer in an immersive and top of the range WWII flight sim, you won't regret your purchase.

												-Premessa ho attivato il gioco su steam anche se lo possiedo dall' agosto 2013-Sim made in Russia, tralasciando il discorso FM questo gioco è chiaramente bilanciato, aerei russi modello gruviera che volano senza risentire dei danni subiti a differenza del 109 che basta guardarlo che va in mille pezzi o del 190 dove con le ali danneggiate diventa inguidabile e altre schifezze che solo online saltano fuori come i Yak più veloci del FW190,E proprio questo aereo probabilmente deve stargli proprio sui coglioni visto che già in alpha è stato oggetto di pesanti critiche da parte della community con tanto di prove cartacee e filmati, problemi corretti in parte dai dev ma con la solita scusina del "ci siamo sbagliati scusate"A differenza di Rise of Flight qui abbiamo un sim dove offline non offre nulla se non una noiosa campagna a missioni offline introdotta da filmati da bimbominkia quando ci sono migliaia di filmati storici in giro, cosa ci voleva a buttargli un misero filmato di 30 secondi? e invece c'è una schifosa scenetta in computer grafica, nessuna modalita carriera e le classiche quick battleOnline si assistono a scene assurde dove i IL2 sono più maneggevoli del Würger, armi laser devastanti sul lagg3 quando storicamente era proprio il contrario, aerei russi che volano quasi tranquillamente anche se fortemente danneggiati nelle ali, i flap degli aerei russi perennemente giù nei dog anche se sono stati in parte corretti, per contro abbiamo gli aerei tedeschi che sono superiori nelle prestazioni pure ma soggetti a strani fenomeni di ondeggiamento stranamente assenti sui russi, ali di metallo che sono più fragili di quelle in legno e così via...Ancora adesso nessuna possibilità di ostare coop.Per usare l' editor ci vuole una laurea e infatti campagne online, non ce ne sono ancora, grandissima mancanza che a distanza di anni dal rilascio di BoS non può più essere tollerataAltra grave mancanza la distanza visiva che è limitata a 9.5km, in soldoni se si vola a 11km di altitudine a terra non vedrete gli aerei perchè non vengono renderizzati, quindi si vola nel deserto per poi imbattersi improvvisamente nei dog.Non esiste varietà nelle munizioni, e CloD qui fa storia, inaccettabile la sola definizione AP e HE... che tipo di HE o AP? no non ci siamoIl bombsight dei bombardieri è più adatto a War ThunderPeccato davvero perchè questo gioco funziona senza impazzire con mod o patch, offre una grande immersione per via della grafica e della fisica e ottime sensazioni "closhe alla mano" ma i problemi di giocabilita piano piano prendono il sopravvento anche sul giocatore più neutrale, non è un caso infatti che questo prodotto è criticato da una buona parte della community online.Insomma, cambia la faccia da IL2 (Oleg e co.) ma il succo rimane lo stesso, il vero problema però rimane che prodotti simili praticamente non esistono, quindi si ingoia e si manda giù, nella speranza che i dev (Russi) sistemino lo stalinwood e le armi tedesche (mg151 in primis) sottomodellateEDIT: 31/01/2017 sistemato il FM del 190, finalmente ora è un vero Würger, dopo 2 anni dal rilascio, vabbè meglio i 2 anni che i 2 weeks di Oleg

Posted: February 20, 2016
												This game is so poorly optimized I've spent seven hours on it just trying to make it run at a playable condition. Too bad even on low this thing refuses to be playable, maybe is not the low fps (keeps dropping from 50 to 40 to 30 and some times to the low mid 20s) but the stuttering that makes it unplayable. When I zoom in, stuttering, when I look around, stuttering, no matter my settings it always happen. Hey is just me flying no vehicles or enemies around, guess what? Yeah, stuttering and unstable fps. I can play War Thunder with 32 players or bots and lots of action on the ground with Ultra settings at full 60 fps in 1080p with not drops just fine but this game on low looks worse than WT and with nothing but just me on the map barely gets to 50 fps, is unstable and still has the stuttering problem. I've read and many people with better specs than me have the same issues. This is obviously a problem with the game. Now as for the gameplay, the lack of content is also a reason why this game isn't worth the price. First of all the game doesn't even have a tutorial mode so for starters like me our only option is to play with custom settings while we learn how the planes handle in this game, which imo is not very good, on normal settings I can't even turn in the 109, while in simulators like 1946 with everything on full realism I can do it without any problem. I found out that I have to enable an option in custom settings to simplify turning, is strange and is something I've never seen in another simulator game so whatever I did it but guess what? The campaign can only be played on normal or expert, that's right the incompetent developers won't even give you the option to play the campaign mode with custom settings, are you kidding me? And if you want to unlock the planes skins and modifications you have to play campaign or pay. So if you can't even turn the fckng plane how are you suppose to do that? PAY. What a joke. And two of the few flyable planes in this game are behind a paywall. One of them is an all time favorite, the 190. Wanna fly the legendary 190, too bad you gotta pay us more for it because is locked unless you pay for the unlock key. Ridiculous. Oh and don't even bother with the mp, is dead. Unless you consider two out of a dozen lobbies being half full alive.Tl;dr - Unplayable overpriced game with a dead mp, very little sp content and very few planes. Good thing I bought it on sale, too bad that by the time I asked for a refund I already exceeded the two hours limit. Not even worth the sale price.IL-2 1946 is still the best ten years later. Cliffs of Dover didn't surpassed it and this one doesn't even come close.

												IL2 in name only.   After shelving it for over a year loaded it back up to see what the latest patch brought, still disappointed. Flight models seem about the same between COD and BOS to me, DCS flight model is superior regarding their ww2 aircraft to date.For WW2 Cliffs of Dover with Team Fusion and even Deastersoft addons, are miles better than these recent IL2 products.   DCS simply blows the doors off IL2, but is more simulator than game (great for us hard-core flight simmers) and not yet really geared towards ww2 fully.   If I had to do it over again for WW2,  I would not buy Battle of Stalingrad, but would buy Cliffs of Dover (TF Mods) as the less serious game and certainly DCS if the Normandy content turns out to be good as a simulator. Tried to give IL2 a chance on multiple occasions now over the last two years but I don't like it for the reasons above.  I would normally say any flight simmer should own all 3, but in this case can't recomment Il2 STalingrad.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												It really isn't a game for casuals like me.I own a controller and all so it's not like that was the issue, but the steep difficulty curve.I understand that complaining about difficulty in a simulator is like complaining about water being too wet, but coming from War Thunder Sim and liking that a fair amount, I thought this would be a natural step up.There was also the framerate issue which even lowest settings couldn't fix, so even on that front the game underperformed.Edit:I do not have the 1-2 week time frame in order to learn how to play the game properly to begin having fun. It is not that I dislike learning how to play games, but I would much rather play a game that is fun immediately --  or almost so -- after starting.Edit(4-8-2017)I've been hearing that there was a switch from Dx9 to Dx11 which apparently improved performance for most systems. While it stopped looking like a slideshow, the framerate frequently remains below 30fps when looking at any trees or buildings or airplanes, and only goes above that when looking at the sky.The settings almost completely lock out the user, with a choice betwen low, medium, high, etc. . ., and a choice to modify AA settings. There is no way to see if many of the post-processing options that are likely available are running, and thus reducing the performance.I have tried the tank combat, but because of the rather hefty lag it was hard to truly appreciate. The AI is stupid, default controls are archaic, and the gunplay didn't feel as impactful -- no real "oomph" when shooting your gun, or feeling of accomplishment when destroying a target.

												Didn't even get past the control setup before I requested a refund for this game. If you use TARGET software the keybinds will not work. For example, flaps in IL2 BOS are 'F' for flaps down and 'left shift + f' for flaps up. If I program these keys into TARGET it will register the 'F' just fine. What it doesn't register is any modifier keys from TARGET such as shift, control, alt ect. When the correct keys are mapped, it would press 'F' for flaps down correctly, and 'F' for flaps up, even though it is mapped as left shift + f in Target. There is a work around but it requires you to set up 4 commands in TARGET for one keybind. I shouldn't have to command TARGET to press left shift, press f, release left shift, release f, just so I can have one keybind. I should be able to just program left shift + f as a singular command like any other game.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
												Don't buy this. That is, unless you're a sadist who likes ridiculous levels of frustration. Now, I didn't go into a flight simulator expecting to be an ace pilot on day one, but I did expect some kind of help or instructional tutorial to help me get off the ground and find my way around the game comfortably. The problem is; I didn't get that. What I got instead was an admittedly beautiful simulator but with comically hillarious levels of poor design from the developers in term of greeting new players. Also, before you direct me to the Youtube guides, I say this: Why are such tutorials not built into the game? Hm? Why have the developers who have created a bloody FLIGHT SIMULATOR not given instructions for new players? Am I expected to keep tabbing out to check a video mid-game just to have a basic understanding on how to take off? I'll pass on that, thank you.I think as a rule of thumb now that I'll be instantly refunding games that lack sufficient effort in the area of assisting new players into the controls, gameplay, environment, etc. It's just ridiculous. You make a game with so much complexity but then skimp out on the instructional aspects? Hell, even a game with thousands of key-bindings like ARMA has tutorials! What's your excuse, IL-2? If I stick to it then yes, maybe I could be comfortable at some point in time playing this game. My point however, is that any game worth it's salt should assist new players in doing this. If not, then your playerbase is going to die off or at the very least, be tiny in size. This was actually somewhat evident, since online for this game is pretty barren (Or seemed that way when I was on).So, no. I don't recommend buying this game. Maybe, MAYBE if it's on sale. At full price though? Given the frustration aspect and giant learning curve with no assistance? No. I'm refunding this instantly.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
												The atmosphere and graphics are good, but I feel marketing has become the primary focus of so many gamemakers now. The game is hard, and I have played many flight sims, but frankly couldn't be bothered to try to turn my PC into a flying machine financially and otherwise.... crashed on all 10 of my takeoff attempts. In the air on low settings the game if beautiful... I love looking around the cockpit, but I just don't dare move my stick for fear of a crash... if you are or always wanted to be an amateur pilot and want to have to feel like you are pressing 120 buttons on a real vintage dashboard just to prevent your plane from going into a stall this game is for you.My negative rating comes from the following: I feel a bit fooled that I invested in an Alpha (also bought 2 extra planes) that promised me a dynamic campaign with depth of experience and instead I get a half-baked campaign I could have had in IL-2 1946. Very dissapointed... I am supprised they call this version ready when it seems to be so much less than promised.Ohh, today launch day, I know many people had Early Access version and yet there was a total of 16 pilots on at midnigth GMT +1... that is dissapointing. It is actually fun to just jump into the plane and open and close the cockpit without daring to touch the controls... I remember the dev saying in an interview "we want a game even complete newbs to flight sims can just jump into" ... I am no newb, I mastered Red Baron 3d, even did good at this company's Rise of Flight, but I am not a trained Messeschmit pilot nor have the time to become one.Unlock of planes for a game this expensive is INSANE. Bad choice. Ohhh and my DLC's don't work and they did in early access.Pros: Detail of aircraftCons: Game is hard, campaign is hard (is it really so hard to make something as good as Dynamix's classic Red Baron?), "fun" factor they promised is not really there more than game released 20 or 10 years ago.

												The Following Need Fixing ASAP!The concept and artwork is brilliant but as in past incarnations, it is (still) riddled with problems.  The below need fixing urgently:1 - The combat view is pointless.  Simply fix the exterior camera view so that it snap-centers behind the aircraft (looking foward) as in past IL-2 games.  You can then look around from there (e.g. using hat switch).2 - The HUD key (default h) should not disable in-game map, map position icon or distance indicators of visible aircraft.  This should ONLY turn off the display bar (compass, altitude, etc.) and the right-side engine control icons.  The map and right-side messages can already be turned off separately.3 - The icon key (default i) should turn off the map position icon and distance indicators of visible aircraft.  This should be separate from HUD control because casual players don't want the display bar (which is pointless anyway as aircraft have these gauges) but like to see the map position icon and distance of visible aircraft.4 - When starting the game, it should automatically attempt sign-in and display the 'play offline' option if this has failed.5 - Prop pitch should be able to be mapped to a slider.6 - In the campaign mode, the 'of' in Battle of Stalingrad shouldn't be capitalised.  This just looks unprofessional.Please at least fix the first three and I'll change to a positive review.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2015
												I have bought every single Maddox games IL2 Sturmovik title since the first one, and even had an email exchange with Oleg (flight sim god) himself. I ran a squadron for 8 years on the old Ubi lobbies through the whole series. I bought Cliffs of dover, and never before had i felt so saddened at how unfinished it seemed to be. I really felt for the developers because it always showed in the past how committed and helpful to the IL2 players they were. IL2 Clod was so disjointed that i put off buying IL2 BoS for a long time. But let me tell you this. I beleive IL2 is now the Sim that Oleg was dreaming of. Its great in this release, and i really feel like, theres no way i could go back to 1946 after having a go of this. I thought i had seen this series die, however now it has been resurrected. Sure i understand some peoples comments about lack of aircraft, however, the detail and damage modelling is tremendous compared to 1946 which i will say, does seem very arcade like in comparison. It would be beutiful to have all theaters, Pacific carrier landings and everything you had in 1946, yes that will be missed. Maybe one day Oleg will add all this in DLC, that would be the next dream. Its a great engine this time. Smooth, and polished way beyond what Clod was. The immersion in this sim on full real settings is superb.

content:
Posted: August 27, 2015
												Fantastic flight sim. This past year, I have been resurrecting an old passion of mine: Flight Simulation/Space Sim. I grew up flying with my father and my granfather was an experimental test pilot in the USAF. I have been an enthusiast all of my life.Because I cannot afford to fly in real life (due to  both time and money), so I currently fly a Saitek X-52 Pro and a TrackIR5 setup. My 'cockpit' is still in the beginning stages, but I hope to add little by little over time. Even though my own setup is rudimentary at best, this game is still likely one of the most realistic and immersive experiences I've ever had.I highly recommend IL-2: BOS, especially if you are a fan of the franchise. They have improved many facets of the game.The one complaint I have (if I must), is that it kind of boasts a narrow focus. In some ways, that can add to the experience. However, there is also a significant drawback. In an ideal world I would like to see a more varied, fleshed-out campaign/story and more aircraft. If nothing else, I wish 1C Studios would put out more content. Whether that be in the way DCS World does it, Expansions on current titles or something else entirely. Really this Con only speaks to what a fan I am of this franchise. I hope to see more from them in the future.In terms of experience, this came can be slightly brutal at first; even to an experienced pilot (virtual or otherwise). However, if you stick with it, you'll quickly get the hang of it. I Spent a week hitting it hard each night for an hour or two, and finally started to get the basics and get a feel for the aircraft.Anyways, pick the game up, it's great!

content:
Posted: September 1, 2015
												First the negatives;BoS does not support clickable cockpits and have directly stated they will not. Clickable cockpits give a direct visual way to familiarize players with a given interface, especially with the helpfulness of mousing over different elements in the pit to help figure out where things are. This is especially important if you are going to switch between multiple aircraft to deal with the workload. In all honesty had I known that the clickable cockpits were not to be featured I would most likely not have bought it. Had I figured it out sooner I would have had it refunded. It's a personal thing; your mileage may vary. This wouldn't be so bad of course if the mapping for HOTAS setups wasn't so... rigid. My HOTAS Warthog for example would benefit greatly by being able to assign modifier buttons to chord multiple controls to a single hat switch for engine management. BoS as far as I can tell does not allow you to use anything but ALT, SHIFT and CTRL for modifiers. This is a limitation that even War Thunder  doesn't have.BoS has serious issues with configuring any of the multiple position switches on the Warthog to do anything useful.The game also has multiple interface issues that range from annoying to exasperating. From icons in the navigation menu being horrendously cryptic (If you need to exit the game to find out the difference between blue and orange bullets you are designing it wrong.) to old-hat keybinding of 20 keys just to get friendly AI to do anything (Come on guys, commo rose is a modern standard for a reason.).Precious little is known about any sort of mod tools for the game as yet, which would greatly benefit from it's expansion the way that IL2: Cliffs Of Dover has. Also when your most complete manual is written by a 3rd party; you have a serious problem.Aside from that BoS gives a solid simulation experience. The sensation of flight is superb and the level of polish is the highest of any simulation in its class at current. They have done amazing things with the spotting system that sits it head and shoulders above it's contemporaries. Moreso than any other sim is the feeling of being "in the moment" above a wintery Russian warzone.Now if only the game would tell me what those stupid bullet colors meant without resorting to the Steam forums.

												I felt it was time to update my old review in line with the many changes since I first made it.Pros- Solid Flight Model- Great Graphics- Regular updates- Friendly community- Scalable difficultyCons- Steam key setup for DLC confusing for new players- Too many Luftwaffe pilots online! ;)The game still looks beautiful and I still find myself taking screen shots all the time because of this. Thanks to the recent expansion, IL-2 Battle of Moscow, there are now even more planes and another large scale map if you decide you want more. The flight models of the aircraft feel very realistic and 1C studios, despite the fact they're a small team, are constantly working to make the aircraft as faithful as possible. The next expansion, Battle of Kuban, looks very promising as it brings a whole bunch of new aircraft of course, including the lend-lease Spitfire and a stunning new map. The new map is very different from the previous ones as Kuban is characterised by the sea and mountains. Furthermore the campaign system is receiving a complete overhaul (for all campaigns) and should feel a lot more dynamic and progressive than it does currently.Overall I'd say that the core gameplay and flight experience is solid, the graphics and great, the singleplayer experience is good and set to be vastly improved upon and the scalability and flexibility of the difficulty settings means it can suit everyone. And for those less interested in the Eastern Front you should know that the Pacific theatre is coming next.I started flying with the mouse and keyboard which is viable and still fun but have since upgraded to using a Saitek x52 Hotas, keyboard, HatTrackIR set up... and I love it.

												I am new the flight sims.  I have a cheap logitech extreme 3d pro, but it works fine for this sim.   It is very challenging at first.  For Newbies to flight sims, spend allot of time in the Quick Missions to get a feel for flying, shooting, and bombing.  Then your ready for fun on real missions.  Great game for the price (got it for 1/2 price when steam had a sale).
